comments.content: Can't identify it. Would like to know as well. Pretty convinced too it's a custom job based on some (recent) commercial brush script. The closest I have for the moment is [Rukola](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nikola-giacintova/rukola) using some stylistic alternates (/ [F](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nikola-giacintova/rukola/regular/glyphs.html#glyphs/623986/577), / [r](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nikola-giacintova/rukola/regular/glyphs.html#glyphs/623986/660), / [d](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nikola-giacintova/rukola/regular/glyphs.html#glyphs/623986/614)). [Signalist](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mika-melvas/signalist) is nice too. Still searching...

New to me. Some similars.  
Emil Bertell's No. Seven [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fenotype/no.-seven/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fenotype/no.-seven/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fenotype/no.-seven/")  
Jason Walcott's Scriptorama Tradeshow [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jukebox/scriptorama-tradeshow-jf/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jukebox/scriptorama-tradeshow-jf/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/jukebox/scriptorama-tradeshow-jf/")  
Michael Hochleitner's Sauber Script [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/sauber-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/sauber-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/sauber-script/")  
Don

Thanks Kevin. Hope someone takes this as a challenge to complete the alphabet and make a font.  
Don

If you want a font with the tone of the lettering in Fitzgeralds, I can now recommend Suzee FY [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontyou/suzee-fy/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140822103231/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontyou/suzee-fy/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontyou/suzee-fy/") as being closer than any of the other suggestions. The \_z\_ and \_g\_ are quite different but the casual reader should accept Suzee FY as a continuation of the Fitzgeralds logo lettering.  
Don
